Post: "I've been battling depression since I was a teenager, and it feels like I'll never be able to escape it. I've tried so many medications, but they never seem to work out for me. I can't even begin to count the number of times I've had suicidal thoughts. It's like my brain is wired to always look for the worst-case scenario. I try to cope by journaling, but it feels like it's not doing anything to help me. I just feel so lost and alone in this struggle."
Transferred_Post: "I've been dealing with depression since my teenage years, and it has been a constant battle. Despite trying various medications, including Wellbutrin, I haven't found a solution that works for me. The hopelessness can be overwhelming, leading to frequent suicidal thoughts. However, I've been trying to cope by journaling, though it's not always effective in alleviating my emotions. It can feel isolating and daunting, but I'm determined to find a way to break this cycle."

Post:
"I can't believe how messed up the world is. It seems like everywhere I look, there's injustice and corruption. The government is controlled by crooks who only care about lining their pockets, and no one seems to care. It feels like the good guys are losing, and it's all just too much for me to handle. I wish someone would do something about it, but it seems like everyone's just sitting back and letting it all happen. It's hopeless."

This post exhibits a global attributional style because it takes a specific event or issue (corruption and injustice in the world) and generalizes it to the entire scope of the speaker's life. The speaker feels that the state of the world is affecting their whole life, not just one aspect of it, and that they are powerless to change it. They also imply that this sense of hopelessness applies to all aspects of their life, not just politics or government.
Transferred_Post: "The current state of the world has been really getting me down lately. It seems like every time I turn on the news, there's another story about corruption or injustice. It's hard for me to see how these issues can be addressed when it feels like the people in power are more interested in lining their pockets than doing what's right. It's especially frustrating because it feels like no one is doing anything about it, and that it's all just too much for me to handle. I wish there was something I could do to help make a difference, but for now, it feels like the good guys are losing. It's really affecting my personal and emotional life, making it hard for me to find hope in other areas of my life."
